data.title: Famous People
data.meta_description: Famous People - Download as a PDF or view online for free
data.text:
William golding, wwii and the cold war

William golding, wwii and the cold warmrbacigalupi

William Golding was a British author born in 1911 who is best known for his novel Lord of the Flies. He studied science at Oxford but later switched to literature. During World War II, Golding served in the Royal Navy and was present at the sinking of the German battleship Bismarck and the Normandy invasion. After the war, he began writing fiction, publishing Lord of the Flies in 1954. The document then provides historical context about World War II and the Cold War that followed, focusing on the ideological divide between the U.S. and Soviet Union that defined the Cold War era.

Trudeau History 3UA3 Slidecast

Trudeau History 3UA3 SlidecastEmily Trudeau

Yevgeny Zamyatin was a Bolshevik revolutionary who was twice exiled and once arrested for his incitement. His novel We depicts a tightly controlled future society where logic and reason prevail in every aspect of life, inspired by Frederick Taylor's theories of scientific management. The novel served as a precautionary tale, influencing later dystopian works like Brave New World that also depicted the logical ends of industrialization and mass control over society.

The Greatest World War II Movies of All Time (part2)

The Greatest World War II Movies of All Time (part2)guimera

The document provides summaries of 16 famous World War II movies, including The Best Years of Our Lives (1946), Rome, Open City (1945), The Imitation Game (2014), and Patton (1970). It describes the directors, writers, main stars, and basic plot summaries for each film. The movies depicted cover a wide range of perspectives and experiences during World War II, such as the challenges faced by veterans returning home, the Italian resistance movement, code breaking efforts, and the life of General Patton.

William golding

William goldingabigailvrgs

William Golding was a British novelist best known for his 1954 novel Lord of the Flies. He served in the Royal Navy during World War II and drew on his experiences to examine human nature. Lord of the Flies tells the story of British boys stranded on an island who try to govern themselves but descend into savagery. Though initially rejected, it became a classic that explores the conflict between civilization and innate human brutality. Golding sought to trace the defects of modern society back to defects in human nature.

The Greatest World War II Movies of All Time (part1)

The Greatest World War II Movies of All Time (part1)guimera

1. The document provides summaries of 20 famous World War II movies, including Schindler's List, Life is Beautiful, Casablanca, Saving Private Ryan, and The Pianist. 2. Many of the movies depict the human toll of the war and the Holocaust, such as Grave of the Fireflies and Come and See, while others like Raiders of the Lost Ark and Indiana Jones involve adventure and escaping the Nazis. 3. Other films profile individuals who helped Jews escape, like Schindler, or examine the fall of Nazi Germany from the perspective of Hitler and his inner circle, as in Downfall.

Austin's

Jesse James was a famous American outlaw who was born in 1847 and grew up robbing banks and trains with his own gang called the Youngers James Gang. He was shot and killed at age 34 by Robert Ford while straightening a picture in his home, making him one of the most famous outlaws in American history and the most wanted man in his time.

Who are the avengers converted

Who are the avengers convertedDigitalmarketingtraininginkolkata

Captain America, Thor, Hulk, and Iron Man are some of the main Avengers in Marvel comics. Captain America was created in 1941 as a patriotic supersoldier who fought in World War 2. Thor is based on the Norse god of thunder and can transform between his alter ego Dr. Blake and Thor using his hammer. The Hulk was created in 1962 and is both a powerful, green-skinned humanoid and his alter ego, the physically weak Dr. Banner. Iron Man is billionaire Tony Stark who was kidnapped and instead created an armored suit to escape and then used to fight crime.

Political films of US and Japan

Political films of US and Japankikampus

The document discusses the history of political and socially conscious filmmaking in the United States from the 1920s through the 1990s. It covers early films made for African American audiences by Oscar Micheaux in the 1920s-1940s. It then discusses the rise of leftist documentary film collectives in the 1930s that addressed issues of poverty and racism. During World War II, propaganda films were produced to explain America's involvement in the war. The 1960s saw the emergence of counterculture and New Left films critical of the Vietnam War. Political films continued in the 1970s reflecting the tumultuous times. The document concludes with brief mentions of Gulf War films in the 1990s and changes in the film industry during that decade

Bitotsav' 15 Entertainment Quiz Challenger

Bitotsav' 15 Entertainment Quiz ChallengerUtsav Giri

This document summarizes information about Harry Potter, music, literature, movies, and Star Wars: 1. It provides background on the fictional character Merlin from the Harry Potter universe. 2. It identifies the band AC/DC and musician Thom Yorke from Radiohead based on biographical details. 3. It outlines the structure of The Silmarillion and describes the setting of Nineteen Eighty-Four. 4. It defines the Rashomon effect seen in the movie Rashomon and identifies the film company Cruel and Unusual Films owned by Zack and Deborah Snyder. 5. It provides background on the Ewoks from Star Wars and identifies that

The War of the Worlds by Mike Cress

The War of the Worlds by Mike Cressmikecress

H.G. Wells' 1898 novel The War of the Worlds tells the story of a Martian invasion of Earth from the perspective of an unnamed narrator. The Martians emerge from cylinders that fall from the sky and begin killing humans with heat rays and poison gas. Their tripod fighting machines allow them to easily overpower human militaries. The narrator flees London and witnesses the Martians constructing giant three-legged machines to continue their conquest. The novel comments on themes of imperialism, warfare, and humanity's place in the universe through the depiction of a hostile alien takeover.

Clinteastwoodpres

Clint Eastwood is an American actor, director, producer, composer, and politician born in 1930 who rose to fame playing the man with no name in Sergio Leone's Dollars trilogy of westerns in the 1960s. He has had success both directing films such as Million Dollar Baby and Unforgiven, for which he won Academy Awards, and starring in many films such as Dirty Harry, The Good the Bad and the Ugly, and Space Cowboys. The document provides a brief biography of Eastwood and lists examples of some of the many films he has both directed and starred in during his long career.

What made us

What made us camphuong

The document discusses several influential individuals and developments in the United States during the late 19th and 20th centuries, including Albert Einstein and his contributions to modern physics, John F. Kennedy's presidency during the Cold War era, the Rockefeller family's success in the oil industry, the rise of the Mafia in America, the development of television, singer Bob Dylan's influence on music and social movements, the opening of Disneyland theme park, actress Marilyn Monroe's fame and impact, the spaceflight of monkeys Able and Miss Baker, and the Lockheed U-2 spy plane shot down over the Soviet Union during the Cold War.

The 1980’s life time

The 1980’s life timeEdwinshkapastrana

The 1980s saw many significant events including the eruption of Mt. St. Helens in 1980, the US hockey team's upset victory over Russia in the 1980 Olympics, and the assassination of John Lennon in 1980. Other notable events included Sandra Day O'Connor becoming the first female Supreme Court justice in 1981, the debut of MTV in 1982, and the Iran-Contra affair beginning in 1985. The decade also saw the assassination attempt on Ronald Reagan in 1981, the release of Michael Jackson's hit song "Thriller" in 1983, and the Challenger disaster in 1986.

The 1980’s life time edwinshka

The 1980’s project

The 1980’s projectmarquisetonini94

The document provides an overview of various people, events, inventions, and cultural trends from the 1980s. It discusses the eruption of Mount St. Helens, the death of John Lennon, Sandra Day O'Connor becoming the first female Supreme Court justice, the emergence of MTV, the Iran-Contra affair, the assassination attempt on Ronald Reagan, the popularity of "Thriller" by Michael Jackson, and more. A variety of topics across news, politics, entertainment, and culture during the 1980s decade are summarized.

We Didnt Start The Fire

We Didnt Start The Firemicdshistory

The document provides biographical information about Billy Joel and the background and context surrounding his 1989 hit song "We Didn't Start the Fire". It discusses Joel's early life, musical career and success in the 1970s. It then describes the release and lyrics of "We Didn't Start the Fire", which references over 120 people, places, events and inventions from 1949 to 1989 in a rapid fire style. It concludes by listing some of the key references from different time periods mentioned in the song.

1980’s power point

1980’s power pointtylerphillips

This document provides brief summaries of various people, events, inventions, and cultural topics from the 1980s. Some of the things summarized include the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens, the US hockey team beating Russia in the 1980 Olympics, the death of John Lennon in 1980 after being shot, Sandra Day O'Connor becoming the first female Supreme Court justice, and the introduction of MTV and the first music television shows.

Early american drama

Early american dramaIin Angriyani

Early American drama began with the first professional company in 1767 and the first theater being built in 1716. Ira Aldridge was the first African American actor to achieve international fame in the 1800s. Eugene O'Neill led innovative American playwrights in the 1920s exploring social issues through plays like A Raisin in the Sun and Death of a Salesman. Later playwrights like Tony Kushner and Moises Kaufman examined issues of gay rights and the AIDS epidemic in works like Angels in America and The Laramie Project.

CONTEXTS AND CONDITION IN 20TH CENTURY (AFTER 1945) AND DRAMA AFTER 1945

CONTEXTS AND CONDITION IN 20TH CENTURY (AFTER 1945) AND DRAMA AFTER 1945Angel Part II

Group 11's lesson focuses on drama in the 20th century after 1945. Some key developments include: 1) The world wars had a major impact on culture and society, including the mixing of cultures and rise of new ideologies. 2) Major British playwrights after WWII include George Bernard Shaw, John Osborne, and Samuel Beckett. Their works often examined themes of identity and the human condition. 3) Important American playwrights were Eugene O'Neill, Arthur Miller, and Tennessee Williams. O'Neill helped innovate drama with works like The Emperor Jones. Miller's Death of a Salesman and Williams' A Streetcar Named Desire both won Pulitzer Prizes.

Name That Mustache, featuring Burt Reynolds and others

Name That Mustache, featuring Burt Reynolds and otherscchelton

This document profiles 16 famous men known for their distinctive mustaches, including Sam Elliott who popularized the walrus mustache, Hulk Hogan's bold horseshoe mustache, and Clark Gable's iconic pencil mustache during his Hollywood career spanning four decades and over 60 films such as Gone with the Wind. Other notable figures featured are Burt Reynolds known for his bushy mustache and macho roles, Salvador Dali and his surrealist upturned mustache, Mark Twain who sported the walrus mustache before Sam Elliott, and Albert Einstein recognized for his contributions to physics and memorable chevron mustache.

The 1980’s

The 1980’sDarianMiranda1994

The document summarizes several notable events from the 1980s decade including: - The 1980 eruption of Mt. St. Helens in Washington which caused an earthquake and blew down 230 square miles of forest. - The US hockey team's upset victory over the heavily favored Russian team at the 1980 Olympic Games in Lake Placid. - The assassination of John Lennon on December 8, 1980 when he was fatally shot outside his New York City apartment building. - Sandra Day O'Connor becoming the first female Supreme Court justice in 1981 after being appointed by President Ronald Reagan.

The 1980’s

The 1980’sDarianMiranda1994

The document summarizes several notable events from the 1980s decade including: - The 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens in Washington which caused an earthquake and blew down 230 square miles of forest. - The US hockey team's upset victory over the heavily favored Russian team at the 1980 Olympic Games. - The assassination of John Lennon on December 8, 1980 when he was shot outside his New York City home. - Sandra Day O'Connor becoming the first female Supreme Court justice in 1981 after being appointed by President Ronald Reagan. - The debut of MTV in 1981 as the first music television network with its first music video being "Video Killed the Radio Star".

Five thriller directors.

Five thriller directors.beckiedonaldson

This document provides information on 5 thriller directors: James Cameron, known for Terminator and Avatar, was born in Canada and is worth $900 million; Steven Spielberg, known for Jaws and Saving Private Ryan, was born in America and is worth $3 billion; Alfred Hitchcock, known for Psycho and The Birds, was born in England; Christopher Nolan, known for The Dark Knight and Inception, was born in England; and John Frankenheimer, known for The Manchurian Candidate and Seconds, was from New York.

The united states of america

The united states of americaolgmikh

This document provides an overview of key people, places, and events in United States history. It mentions Christopher Columbus and Native Americans, then describes important landmarks in Washington D.C. and other major cities like Boston, New York, Chicago, and Los Angeles. Figures highlighted include George Washington and his cabinet, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, and holidays like Thanksgiving and Independence Day. The document also discusses the film industry in Hollywood and influential stars like Mary Pickford and Clark Gable, best known for Gone With the Wind.

Business Plan - Comics

Business Plan - Comics Dato Mamuchadze

Georgian Comics aims to create and offer something new to readers by translating comic books and graphic novels. Their goals are to release short-term comic books and graphic novels from popular comic universes to make them more accessible, as well as to eventually translate Japanese manga. They need $50,000 to start the business and aim to sell at least 50,000 comic issues per year by the first Saturday of May, utilizing social media, schools, and newspapers for marketing.

"Dracula" by Bram Stoker

"Dracula" by Bram StokerDato Mamuchadze

Bram Stoker's 1897 novel "Dracula" tells the story of Count Dracula's battle against a small group of people led by Jonathan Harker. The story is narrated through letters and diaries and follows young solicitor Jonathan Harker's journey to Transylvania to help Count Dracula move from Transylvania to England. However, Harker soon realizes he has become a prisoner in Dracula's castle. Although Harker escapes, Dracula sets his sights on Mina, Harker's fiancée. Harker and his friends, including Professor Abraham Van Helsing, must find a way to stop the monster Count Dracula.
